content.question: Which of the following best explains a distinction between metaphase <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and metaphase <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The nuclear membrane breaks down during metaphase <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> but not during metaphase <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Chromosomes align at the equator of the cell during metaphase <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> but not during metaphase <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The meiotic spindle is needed during metaphase <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> but not during metaphase <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Homologous pairs of chromosomes are aligned during metaphase <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, but individual chromosomes are aligned during metaphase <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: Homologous pairs of chromosomes are aligned during metaphase <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, but individual chromosomes are aligned during metaphase <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
